scenes.dialogue_vo: Hook: TL;DR in 3 — facts, rules, agenda. CLIPS is the OG rule engine that’s also object-oriented and procedural. Let’s shred a knowledge base in 60 seconds. Ready? Go — fast brainrot mode ON! 🧠⚡️

ELI5: Facts are sticky notes, rules are the matching filters, and the inference engine is the scheduler that decides what fires. If a rule keeps firing, blame the agenda or refraction — usually one of those two. Watch me debug it live.
Show the difference: ad-hoc facts vs templates. Ad-hoc is messy — use deftemplate for structure. Templates = form fields for reliable matching. Big brain move.
Show the difference: ad-hoc facts vs templates. Ad-hoc is messy — use deftemplate for structure. Templates = form fields for reliable matching. Big brain move.
Show the difference: ad-hoc facts vs templates. Ad-hoc is messy — use deftemplate for structure. Templates = form fields for reliable matching. Big brain move.

asset.description: A hyperactive close-up of a young office worker in an over-lit open-plan office suddenly slamming three neon-colored sticky notes labeled "FACTS," "RULES," and "AGENDA" onto a pristine white desk in rapid succession while the camera whip-pans between each note, then snap-zooms out to reveal the worker now wearing a cheap plastic wizard hat and oversized gaming headset, aggressively typing on an ancient beige terminal computer with a CRT monitor flickering green code; the camera circles around their head in a slightly shaky handheld motion as half-eaten snacks, empty energy drink cans, and random rubber ducks slide slowly across the desk, and in the deep background a coworker dressed in a business suit casually shreds a stack of paper labeled "KNOWLEDGE BASE" with a tiny manual paper shredder, staring deadpan into the camera as bits of paper drift in slow motion through a harsh fluorescent light beam.

bgm: Fast, glitchy EDM with heavy hi-hats and sidechain pump, very short 2-bar loop energy to feel like TikTok brainrot.

asset.description: The shot opens on a perfectly symmetrical overhead view of a clean white table where a bored-looking office worker’s hands start slapping down bright sticky notes labeled "FACT" in crooked handwriting, forming a loose pile; the camera slowly tilts down to eye level as another hand slides in a cheap plastic kitchen strainer labeled "RULES" in bold marker, and the worker begins awkwardly pouring the sticky notes through the strainer so some fall to the floor, some stick to the mesh, and one gets stuck on their forehead without them noticing; the camera then dollies sideways to reveal a tiny toy desk calendar and alarm clock labeled "AGENDA" that suddenly gets surrounded by miniature sticky notes standing upright like people in line, while the worker frantically tries to organize them with two mismatched highlighters, repeatedly dropping them, glancing nervously at the clock, and then turning in slow motion to stare at the camera as one stubborn sticky note keeps bouncing back from the trash can onto the table.

bgm: Light quirky lo-fi beat with playful bass, still fast-paced but less intense than hook.

asset.description: Use the "Small Brain vs Big Brain" ascending galaxy brain meme. Panel 1 (small brain): Caption text over an image of a dimly lit brain: "Ad-hoc facts: random lists of stuff, hope the pattern matcher just vibes." Panel 2 (medium brain): "Some structure... sometimes... maybe?" with a faintly glowing brain. Panel 3 (big bright brain): "deftemplate with proper slots = form fields, reliable matching, future-you won’t hate you." Panel 4 (galaxy brain exploding): "BIG BRAIN MOVE: everything is a template, even your ‘quick hack’ facts."

bgm: Playful trap-style plucky arpeggios, meme-y but still techy.

asset_plan.scene_name: Scene 4 - Code time: define template & assert facts (terminal)

asset.description: The scene begins with an extreme close-up of a dusty old CRT monitor showing a blinking command-line cursor on a dark background, then the camera slowly pulls back to reveal a person in an ill-fitting blazer and pajama pants hunched over a tiny keyboard perched on a stack of pizza boxes, their fingers hammering dramatically but inconsistently as CLIPS-style code lines appear on screen in perfect rhythm with the keystrokes; the camera cuts to a low-angle side shot where the monitor glow flickers across a wall covered in crooked sticky notes labeled "TEMPLATE" and "FACT" with red string randomly connecting them in nonsensical patterns, while the person squints, leans way too close to the screen, and nods intensely after each line appears; finally the camera snap-zooms into the terminal window itself, where the code text suddenly scrolls smoothly as if typed by an invisible hand, reflections of the scrolling code faintly visible in a nearby mug of cold coffee as the person raises both hands triumphantly like they just hacked the mainframe.

bgm: Steady techy synth beat, mid-tempo, giving a "coding montage" vibe without being too aggressive.
